Pros:
-Open level up system that feels constantly rewarding

Cons

Don't let the Newgrounds era flash looking graphics throw you off, this game is actually quite a gem. The story is light and fairly predictable, but keeps your interest with quirky characters that do a good job both paying homage to and flipping cliche conventions. While not the most well-rounded around, the main cast is generally likable (Especially Lina, she's adorable and spunky without being overbearing or annoying) and the NPC's form an oddball cast that--while not terribly memorable--serve the purpose of keeping you entertained.

This is very much a game intended to appeal only to fans of the genre looking for a quick, light revisit to the old JRPG glory days. In that, it delivers wonderfully. Fans of old-school Final Fantasy and Dragon Quest and the like will find all of this wonderfully familiar, and should have absolutely no trouble jumping right in. For some, the 'been there, done that' aspect of it might be a turn off, but for me, it was exactly what I was looking for. A fun, accessible turn-based battle system, and a slightly unconventional level up system (you apply your points directly to learning skills or gaining ability points, rather than it happening automatically, with new paths unlocking once each is complete--it's basically a stripped down version of Final Fantasy X's Sphere Grid), combined with the ability to both improve your equipment, and forge new adds much needed depth, and gives the game a spot on balance between easily accessible and customizable.

It's not breaking any new ground, but it's not really aiming to. If you're looking for a fun look back at the great JRPG's of the past, you could do much worse than this little fling.

This is a really good game, reccomended to RPG fans and bored people how have some spare cash. Remember that this is my first reveiw, and I haven't finished the game.


The art style is hit or miss, depending on your preferances, but in my opinion it works quite well for the game. The art matches the tone of Crystal Story 2, so I think it works.

The combat is well crafted, and fun! The enemies have interesting designs, and I actually found it pretty enjoyable. The timer, I guess you would call it, is also interesting. It shows when the enemies/characters can tke an action, and where they are on the timer (it's kind've a scale) can be changed by multiple things-stun for example. I've never seen this mechanic before, so props to the developer! The mutiple debuffs and buffs are fun to use, and some enemies have interesting attack patterns, the Friendly Sprite, for example. It always get's to take action first. On it's first turn, it buffs another monster/itself. Then it's fast enough to get back to the top of the scale, and either buffs another monster (or itself) or attacks.

The plot is a pretty baic 'save the world' narrative, which I'm fine with. Nothing else to say here.

The inventory system is well made. It's not a giant overlay of thousands of menus, it's just a few compact menus packed together nicley.  You can equip armor, which I honestly haven't found much of.

The last thing I'm going to touch on is the class system. It's not your standard clas system. Yes, each character does start out with a base class, but you can get them more classes overtime. That's confusing, I know. So, each charcter has a class. You can click on the class icon and acess this tree-ish menu. You use 'SP' to 'buy' stat upgrades to your character, and also to get spells, that are all on this long line of stat boosts. After you've gotten every stat boost and spell for a given character's class, you can give your chracter a new class. It's a well made mechanic, that I like!


Over all, I'll give it a 8.5/10. It's a very good game.

reviewText:
A great JRPG, but only for fans who're fond of the formula. If you do no like Final Fantasy, or others in this genre, then this game is not for you. The game runs smoothly, and the glitches are small, such as dismantling a talisman giving an amethyst instead of a sapphire. The story is present, and not horrible, but able to be skipped. It has a few easter eggs buried in here for those who look, but other than that the story is a basic JRPG one, saving the world from ancient disaster, all that kind of stuff. Playing the original browser game is uneeded to understand the story, although they do make some jokes for those who've played it.

Combat is good, with higher level enemies and bosses needing a fair amount of planning to defeat. Most fights aside from the bosses are able to be avoided, and grinding is not needed until the post-game, if you play your cards right. Plus the battle arena makes grinding coming down to mostly skill. The boss fights are somewhat sub-par to FF standards, but the final boss meets this just fine. For the price, it gives a few hours of enjoyment, plenty of side quest bosses, plus a very challenging post game that really pushes you.

In terms of tips, the battle area x is great for gaining levels and items post game, plus the stat boost items when using dice. Never use alchemy for equipment other than weapons because you can find those as drops, and use the alchemy deconstruction on the start and last stat boost equipment to rack up as much scrap needed to upgrade weapons as possible. Pray to RNJesus for dice and other rare gear early on, Hold off from buying items in bulk until you get the 25% discount in the water temple, get only what you need until then. The locked blue chests contain rare cards, and the key is hidden in the final level, so don't stress yourself looking how to open it. Save rare items like elixer brews and rocket burst bombs for the final boss fight. Don't be afraid to have a charactor take a different class for a level, as gaining important skills, like buffs, is important since every charactor learns different spells from the same class. Debuffs can fail, and its best to use one with a speedy charactor who can cast them in rapidly to hope one lands on the boss (speedy thief is best for this). Finally, your weapon level decides your ultimate, so you cannot get the achievements for using them until they're level 2 or above, and you unlock the final one at level 4,

reviewText:
An indie RPG worth every penny. Not a masterpiece in any sense of the word, as the story is mainly just for giggles and give you a flimsy reason to play, but the characters are charming enough, and the inclusion of the first game means there is a lot of content to be had.

Of course, the game wouldn't be worth playing through the content, but CSII is a sublime distillation of RPGs and their battle system. There is always decent difficulty, but the challenges posed against you are always fair, and fair warning is almost always given when you may be going in over your head. You can blow through the main campaign rather quickly, but the real attraction here is the sidequests and the variety of boss monsters you get to face. There is a lot of wonderful loot, and the upgrade trees available through leveling are pure freedom, as you can more or less make each character into whatever strange hybrid of classes you like. This is the first RPG in a long time where I actually looked forward to battles, which is an admitted rarity these days.

If you aren't feeling a classic battle however, there are a handful of well-thought out minigames that break up the potential monotany. All are optional, but they provide a charming time and show just how much love the developer has for this game. There's a charming couple takes on match 3 gameplay just because, and there's a surprisingly thought out card game that you can check out whenever you want. Neither are perfect, but the card game in particular is deceptively intellegent in its execution, but simple enough to pick up. Honestly, if it was to ever be fleshed out more, it could make a decent standalone, though a bit threadbare at the moment.

Crystal Story II is definitely a love letter. Flawed, fun, and evidence of a work of passion, its sense of humor and immense amount of content only began to wear on me around the 50 hour mark, and is a game I plan on finishing to completion somewhere down the road. A great addition to anyone's library to see just how great an indie RPG can be.

If you're anything like me, you had a couple of dollars doing nothing in your Steam account and saw this game pop up either on a sale or just in a general search.

So, the question is... is it worth it?

Crystal Story 2 is a classic-style JRPG about four unlikely heroes that save the... okay, it's not the most original story in the world. But the story unfolds in an entertaining, often humorous way, using cliches seemingly by design. This is evidenced by numerous references to other JRPGs of the past like Final Fantasy Mystic Quest and Breath of Fire. Ultimately, it wears the cliche hat proudly and doesn't try to be anything more.

If you're worried about missing something from the first game, never fear. The game comes complete with the first game included!

The gameplay style of Crystal Story is standard dungeon-crawling fair, either clicking your destination on the screen or WASDing your way around. Encounters are seen on screen and can be avoided a la Earthbound and Chrono Trigger, which is always a welcome addition. In addition to the main storyline, there are also numerous sidequests, often involving chasing down and taking out a boss monster.

Battles are very fluid and fast-paced in this game. The way it plays out is familiar to anyone who's played a Super NES RPG. On the left side of the screen, you see a meter with every participant on it, rising to the top. Once someone's icon  reaches the top of the meter, they may perform an action. Again, pretty straightforward.

One of the ways this game excels is the level of character customization. While Crystal Story 1 features a mostly linear leveling system dedicated to investing points into learning new skills, Crystal Story 2's character growth system is almost bafflingly expansive. as you progress, you choose one of six class specializations, which opens up an experience tree. For each step on the tree, you invest an increasing number of experience points (or SP, in this game). These tiles can either be a set stat increase, a new ability, or a choice stat increase, in which you can choose which one of two stats to increase.

This seems complicated, but it truly isn't. The level up system in the game is incredibly intuitive and allows a ton of customization as you make your numbers go up in general. One minor complaint I have about the system, however, is that maybe it's a little TOO precise. Often it feels like more trouble than it's worth opening up the level up screen in the menu and distributing points. It's a slow and often flow-breaking process.

The game also boasts mini games such as a Pipe Dreams style lock-picking game, fishing, and a simple puzzle game which is nonetheless fun in and of itself. Even if the puzzle game in question basically comes free on most smart phones these days.

As for the music? It's fantastic. The tunes are incredibly memorable and really capture the mood of each scene. Even the simple opening title music has a way of sticking in your head sometimes.

There's not much to say about the graphics. They're fairly simple in a hand-drawn, anime sort of style. Storylines unfold via stillframe cutscenes which won't light the world on fire. That said, the simple style of the graphics makes it incredibly easy to tell where and what everything is at a glance, making the visuals intuitive and easy on the eyes.

The main storyline of both games are relatively short, but they both have a lot of post-game content to keep you amused.

Ultimately, it boils down to this: did I get 3 dollars worth of entertainment out of this? Definitely. It's a straightforward game with old-school JRPG fans in mind. As such, your enjoyment of this will likely depend on how much you like that style of gaming.

Okay, WOW!

This game caught me off-guard; I didnt expect to see something so... well-made and polished. I mean, it's simplistic in its core and could probably be improved if the developer felt it was needed, but as it is right now, the game is pretty amazing in how downright CHARMING it is!

Avoid this game if you're the kind who looks for the super-defined graphics that the bigger companies are churning out, but this game is a definite MUST if you can appreciate the simpler and finer things in a game (like the hotkeys for selecting attacks and targets, something as small as that).

My compliments to the maker for a job well done on this! Definitely something I'd recommend and gift to friends!

reviewText:
This game, there's so much I have to say about this game....

Pros:
- all leveling comes through a sp grid, and you gain sp based on what enemies you fight
- even though each of your main characters have a different sp grid setup so they try and make them fall into preset roles, everyone can eventually learn anything which allows for some extreme versatility
- All four characters have rather deep personas you learn about through the game, thus making you learn about them seem fun.
- The dialogue in this game is a BLAST I was laughing uproariously at many points in this game
- You can name your characters, this might not seem like much but I named my main character Doofus, insanity ensued.
- Some of your party members leave at certain points in the game (CHAP 4 DARN YOU!), but when they return any additional sp you have gained in battles they obtain as well, meaning no one is left behind.
- Although most bosses are immune to some status effects, nearly every boss is susceptible to at least one status effect or another, often times they are only resistant meaning hitting them enough times allow said status to stick
- There's a very nice difficulty curve in this game, it steadily increases through the game, and the bosses get harder as you go along, of course I don't find any of them very challenging until you get to the boss of chp4
- the game is fun to go through, there's no point where the story really drags, and everything is genuinely fun to go through, and since you can freely travel the world map once you complete an area you can go back and heal once you beat each area if you desire to.

Cons:
- This is a nitpick for me but, one of your characters is a demon, I don't like that
- You have both physical, and elemental attacks in this game, though it becomes obvious very early on that elemental attacks are MUCH more effective than any physical attacks are.
- If you build a special attack weapon (which I did) give it to the sheriff, and then teach her an aoe ability she will screen nuke EVERYTHING in the game besides bosses.
- Despite each characters originality they all in battle will eventually fall into a 'jack of all trades' category


Overall the pros greatly overwhelms the cons in this game, this in my opinion is the #1 game on steam I've played so far, yes trumping even Dreamscape

reviewText:
A surprising amount to this game considering the price.


A fairly traditional J-RPG, with a turn-based / ATB mix system similar to Grandia, where the time bar fills up, and time pauses when a character reaches the action stage, allowing you to enter a command.

The Level up system is like Final Fantasy 13's EXCEPT with a lot more freedom & customisation; instead of levelling up, you earn skill points that you spend on a series of skill trees. You pick one of (trying to remember the number...) ~6 classes, which each gives different stat bonuses & moves, depending on the character in question. Once you complete the path of ~25 'nodes' you can pick another class to continue on. After completing 2 classes, you then pick from the original group again, except the classes are now Rank 2, and have new stat & skill rewards for the tree.
Also, every fifth or so node will give you the choice between 1 of 2 rewards, so you can actually vastly change your party as time goes on - I had one character receiving only Attack & HP boosts to the best of my ability, leaving a slow and powerful guy who's next to impossible to kill; I also made 2 characters focus on All-hitting attacks with high speed, so they can continually barrage the enemies with solid amounts of damage. The 4th character I focused on a range of magic abilities, so that powerful healing and damage could be carried out against more physically-oriented enemies.


Enemies roam about on the field map, the standard 'don't want to battle, don't make contact' system; dungeons are broken into squares, with all the enemies per square acting as one unit - you make contact, you fight all the enemies on the screen as one. There's room to exploit this to find certain enemies for items, which isn't necessarily a bad thing.


Story-wise it's pretty standard, 'Save the world from a thing, slowly learn more about it' - it nicely frames the gameplay, and has some nice characters; nothing exceptional, but it all tends to work within the game's desired atmosphere. I've only finished one chapter, so it could develop far more than I've seen. I should add that the chapter end wasn't too hard-hitting or notable - indeed, I only noticed because of the achievement popping up!


I'm not sure if it would get worse, but it has a few issues regarding simple grinding to break the flow of combat - once you unlock the battle arena you are immediately treated to a fight against several groups of weak enemies that yield a large amount of skill points, crafting parts and money in one go (enough to power through multiple nodes early on); there is no restriction to the number of times you can do this, so with each character having a Hit-All move, this can be quickly rushed through several times, granting far more rewards than it deserves to...were you patient enough this could probably see a person reaching end-game strength within a couple of hours, potentially. Obviously this isn't that bad, just don't do it - or do it,if that's your bag. Some people would probably call this a bonus feature.


Graphically it is what it is, nothing really goes against the visual style you see. Some breaks and odd parts in various dungeons, but really nothing bad enough to warrant discrediting the game for it.


Waffle waffle etc etc. It will at most be a few £s, and it's definitely worth it if the above sounds acceptable to you - I got it for 99p in a sale, definitely glad I gave it a shot; for me, it rivals a few chart J-RPGs I've bought in the past. It does the genre proud, at a time when it's mostly fading into obscurity.
